text:
Sixth Ave, north from Greenwich Ave, showing 8th Street elevated station. Jefferson Market Police Court is seen in left foreground.

About 1890.

Eugene L. Armbruster, Collection.

Christopher Street, west from Greenwich Avenue as viewed from Sixth Avenue (under the "El").

Mr. Sperr reports the following: "John Masefield, as a young man worked in Luke O'Connors Saloon which appears at the left (S.W. corner)."

J. J. Corell
P. L. Sperr

1900

Greenwich Avenue, east side, north from Christopher Street to 30 Greenwich Avenue north of 10th Street, showing old Jefferson Market and the old jail. Subway construction is going on underneath Greenwich Avenue.

August 20, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
Sixth Ave., at the convergence of Greenwich Ave. (foreground) and Christopher Street on the west side of same, viewing eastward to show the Eighth Street station of the Sixth Ave. Elevated Line. Buildings shown across same are on the east side of the Ave. from 8th (right) to 9th (left) Streets. Note in the left foreground the foundation work for the new Womens Detention Prison (former site of the old Jefferson Market).

December 31, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
A northward view on the east side of Sixth Ave., from West 8th Street.

May 1, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)
Similar to No. 1, but viewed northeastward on Christopher Street. On the extreme left is Greenwich Ave., and a corner of the new Women's Prison.

September 8, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
Sixth Ave., at the convergence of Greenwich Ave. (foreground) and Christopher Street on the west side of same, viewing eastward to show the Eighth Street station of the Sixth Ave. Elevated Line. Buildings shown across same are on the east side of the Ave. from 8th (right) to 9th (left) Streets. Note in the left foreground the foundation work for the new Womens Detention Prison (former site of the old Jefferson Market).

(1)
Sixth Avenue at N.W. corner of Greenwich Avenue, showing bed of Minetta Creek and site of old Jefferson Market. December 31, 1929.
P.L.Sperr, Photographer.

(2)
The same from Greenwich Avenue and viewing northward. Demolition in the foreground is for the new Detention House for Women.
1929.

(1)
Sixth Avenue at N.W. corner of Greenwich Avenue, showing bed of Minetta Creek and site of old Jefferson Market. December 31, 1929.
P.L.Sperr, Photographer.

(2)
The same from Greenwich Avenue and viewing northward. Demolition in the foreground is for the new Detention House for Women.
1929.

Jefferson Market Courthouse and tower, seen from Greenwich Avenue, east side, between Christopher and 10th Streets.
December 31, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
Sixth Ave., north from Greenwich Ave. On the left, appears the new Detention House for Women; Formerly the site of Jefferson Market.

October 13, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
A view of the newly completed building, which replaced the old landmark that stood here for years. Shown is the Greenwich Ave., side.

October 13, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)
The same; from the street level. Note the Christmas Trees for sale in the foreground.

December 24, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
Sixth Ave., north from Greenwich Ave. On the left, appears the new Detention House for Women; Formerly the site of Jefferson Market.

October 13, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
A view of the newly completed building, which replaced the old landmark that stood here for years. Shown is the Greenwich Ave., side.

October 13, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)
The same; from the street level. Note the Christmas Trees for sale in the foreground.

December 24, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)

(2)

October 13, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)
The same; from the street level. Note the Christmas Trees for sale in the foreground.

December 24, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
Sixth Ave., at the S.W. corner of Greenwich ave., as viewed from the 8th Street station of the Sixth Ave. Elevated Line, showing the automobile parking space, occupying that area. Also shown (left) are the rears of 3-story houses, facing on Gay Street, and bearing Nos. 13 to 19 (left to right). Adjoining same, and northward, is a 7-story warehouse (H, Behlen & Co.), facing on and bearing Nos. 12-10 Christopher Street. No. 8 Christopher Street, is the Pirates Den. Prominently shown (left to right) are the 12-story Heptagon Building (Nos. 147-153 Waverly Place), and a 17-story apartment house (No. 45 Christopher Street), between Waverly Place and Seventh Ave. South.

October 3, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

(2 & 3)
A set of 2 views showing the same location at an earlier date and prior to clearance.

October 11, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
Sixth Ave., at the S.W. corner of Greenwich ave., as viewed from the 8th Street station of the Sixth Ave. Elevated Line, showing the automobile parking space, occupying that area. Also shown (left) are the rears of 3-story houses, facing on Gay Street, and bearing Nos. 13 to 19 (left to right). Adjoining same, and northward, is a 7-story warehouse (H, Behlen & Co.), facing on and bearing Nos. 12-10 Christopher Street. No. 8 Christopher Street, is the Pirates Den. Prominently shown (left to right) are the 12-story Heptagon Building (Nos. 147-153 Waverly Place), and a 17-story apartment house (No. 45 Christopher Street), between Waverly Place and Seventh Ave. South.

October 3, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

P. L. Sperr.

October 11, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

Sixth Ave., west side, south from, but not including Greenwich Ave., showing the St. Joseph's R.C. Church, at the N.W. corner of Washington Place, and The Waverly, a 16-story apartment house, at the S.W. corner of Waverly Place. Also shown, (in the background), is a 12-story apartment house, at the S.W. corner of Cornelia Street, and a portion of the 8th Street Station of the Sixth Ave. Elevated Line (in foreground).

P. L. Sperr.

October 3, 1931.

Southeast on northeast side of Greenwich Avenue from 12th Street to its southeastern terminus at Sixth Avenue.
March 16, 1933.
P.L. Sperr, Photographer.
Jefferson Market Court House. About 1935. 6th Ave. & Greenwich Ave. at Christopher and W. 9th St.
